name: Augsburg
fun_fact: Fun fact: Augsburg is nicknamed 'Datschiburg' because of its signature Zwetschgendatschi plum cake! The city is also home to the Fuggerei - the world's oldest social housing complex still in use (founded 1521), where rent is still less than 1 Euro per year. Residents must be Catholic, demonstrate financial need, and pray three times daily for the souls of the Fugger family. The Fugger banking dynasty was so wealthy during the Renaissance that they financed emperors, popes, and kings, rivaling nation-states.

hero_dishes.name: Schweinshaxe (Pork Knuckle)
hero_dishes.description: Roasted pork knuckle marinated for days, slow-cooked until brown and crispy outside, juicy and tender inside, served with boiled potatoes or sauerkraut
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Bavarian showstopper and Oktoberfest favorite. Marinated and slow-roasted in the skin, this tender meaty staple represents the hearty, celebratory food culture of Bavaria. Traditionally served with tangy sauerkraut, potato dumplings, and gravy.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Beer gardens like Riegele Biergarten (brewery next door with fresh beer), Thorbr√§u (one of Germany's oldest breweries, founded 1582), and traditional Bavarian restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Zwetschgendatschi (Augsburg Plum Cake)
hero_dishes.description: Sheet cake with shortcrust pastry (M√ºrbteig) generously topped with halved Italian plums, best served lukewarm with cinnamon and whipped cream
hero_dishes.origin_story: Claims exist that this cake was invented in Augsburg where it's considered the city's signature dish. It resembles the 'Zirbelnuss' (pine cone) in the city's coat of arms, giving Augsburg the nickname 'Datschiburg.' 'Datschi' comes from dialect word 'detschen' meaning 'pinching' (as plums are pinched into dough). The original Augsburg version uses shortcrust pastry, while other Bavarian regions use yeast dough.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bavarian bakeries throughout Augsburg, especially traditional cafes and pastry shops

hero_dishes.description: Dumplings made from liver, bread, eggs, and spices, cooked in beef broth and served as Leberkn√∂delsuppe (liver dumpling soup)
hero_dishes.origin_story: An extremely popular dish in Augsburg that showcases the Swabian-Bavarian tradition of using all parts of the animal resourcefully. The hearty soup is a comforting classic in the region.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional German restaurants and beer gardens throughout Augsburg

signature_drinks.description: Fresh local beers from historic breweries
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Riegele Biergarten has the brewery right next door so the beer couldn't be fresher. Thorbr√§u (founded 1582) is one of Germany's oldest breweries, brewing by Augsburg's own beer purity laws from 1156 - 360 years before Bavaria's Reinheitsgebot.

signature_drinks.description: Beer mixed with lemonade, refreshing for warm days
